[Laughter] DAVID:Â  But I need you, for the readers, to give a short explanation of decidability and undecidability. Then hereâ€™s the question. How much does undecidability correlate with technical debt and our inability to understand or test code? Because that was a huge takeaway for me from this book. TOM:Â  Wow. Okay. My brain is churning. [Laughter] TOM:Â  So a short explanation of decidability. Think about a subset of all the problems we might want to solve with computers. There are certain kinds of problems which is called decision problems. A decision problem is where we just want to ask a computer a question to which the answer is yes or no. So this is like a predicate method that you would write in Ruby. You want to know, read in an integer and tell me is it even, yes or no. So these problems are called decision problems. And decidability is the issue of whether one of these decision problems is effectively always answerable. That particular question of whether a number is even is decidable, because for any number that you feed into a computer, itâ€™s possible Iâ€™m being extremely vague here, but you can write a program in Ruby that will tell you whether a number is even or not. That decision problem is decidable. I go into some detail in the book to explain that there are other kinds of problems that are not decidable in that way. Some of those problems, to get onto the actual substance of your question, some of those problems are unfortunately problems that we would really like to be decidable. So this is something that, again, was never quite, when you read textbooks about computation theory, I feel like they go 90% of the way to the exciting point. And the 90% is like, â€œHereâ€™s a load of mathematical prerequisites. Weâ€™re going to talk about GÃ¶del numbering and weâ€™re going to talk about GÃ¶delâ€™s first and second incompleteness theorem and all of this stuff and formal logics and arithmetic and all of this kind of stuff.â€ And you get this amazing result at the end about the existence of undecidable problems. Then they stop as if you get it now. Like, â€œOkay, weâ€™ve showed you a mathematical result. So there you have it.â€ I think even when people are taught this in a more practical setting, people who do understand how the halting problem applies to computer programs, I expect if you were to grab a random Ruby programmer and say, â€œCan you summarize whatâ€™s the deal with the halting problem? What does it mean that the halting problem is undecidable?â€ Theyâ€™ll probably say, â€œWell, you canâ€™t write a computer program that will tell you for sure whether or not a computer program is ever going to finish executing or not.â€ And youâ€™re like, â€œWell okay. But so what? Whatâ€™s the last step of this? Why do we care?â€ Is that just a stupid academic result? It doesnâ€™t sound like something thatâ€™s going to have any consequences for me. I write web interfaces to databases. I do not write programs that tell me whether other programs are ever going to halt or not. Itâ€™s very easy to get into this mindset of even if youâ€™ve understood it maybe you havenâ€™t internalized the consequences of it. One of the things that try in a small way to explain in the book is that this is actually massively relevant. This is why our lives are so painful. Because the halting problem, there are lots of other problems that are reducible to the halting problem that we really want to be able to solve. Things like, does this program satisfy its specification? Does this program have any bugs in it? Does this program make any private API calls? Basically, and this is the depressing conclusion that I come to in that chapter on decidability, is basically anything that you want to know that is interesting about a computer program, in general, is undecidable. It may well be the case that in the vast majority of cases, it actually is decidable but thereâ€™s always going to be this bit of grit. Thereâ€™s always going to be this fly in the ointment which is like, â€œThere are always going to be programs that you want to ask questions about for which these decision problems are not answerable.â€ So even if you think you have written a program that can tell me whether my program is going to run out of memory or whether itâ€™s going to segfault or whether it makes a particular API call or not, I will always be able to cook up a program that when I feed it to your decider, it gives the wrong answer. So the idea of the Goldbach Conjecture is this question of, the question is about whether every even number can be expressed as a sum of two prime numbers, so every even number greater than two. So is there any even number that cannot be expressed as a sum of two prime numbers, essentially. If you think, four is two plus two and six is three plus three and eight is three plus five and ten is three plus seven and so on. And you can keep going. And if you look at all of the even numbers, you can check, just by looking at all of the prime numbers that are less than that number and adding them together and seeing if they make that even number, you can figure out whether there are two prime numbers that add together to make it. It turns out, empirically, every even number that weâ€™ve checked this for, that is the case. I canâ€™t remember exactly how many weâ€™ve checked. I think itâ€™s up to, might be four quintillion. Is that right? JOSH:Â  Itâ€™s a lot. TOM:Â  Yes. A computer has sat down and exhaustively checked this for a large number of even numbers. So just based on the weight of evidence, it certainly seems like every even number greater than two is expressible as the sum of two prime numbers. But we donâ€™t actually have a proof that this is the case. JAMES:Â  Itâ€™s the black swan thing. All weâ€™ve seen so far are white swans but that doesnâ€™t mean thereâ€™s no black swan. TOM:Â  Sure. So maybe thereâ€™s an astronomically large even number that is in fact not the sum of two primes. We donâ€™t have a conclusive proof that that even number doesnâ€™t exist. Thatâ€™s really frustrating because itâ€™s very easy to, and I go through this in the book, itâ€™s very easy to write a program that checks this. So you can write a program that sit there checking the Goldbach conjecture for specific cases, checking it for four then for six then for eight and seeing whether there are two prime numbers that can add together to make that even number. That can keep going for as long as you like. If you set up that program such that it will finish if it ever finds an even number that is not the sum of two primes, and it keeps going forever, modulo available RAM and stuff on the computer, it will keep going forever if it never finds an even number that isnâ€™t the sum of two primes. Then youâ€™ve got yourself a program whose halting behavior is intimately connected to a problem in mathematics that we donâ€™t know the answer to. So for that specific program, without getting into anything complicated or self-referential or metaphysical, I can just say if you look at that program, you canâ€™t tell me whether thatâ€™s ever going to halt or not just because itâ€™s a difficult question. But even beyond that, the stuff to do with the halting problem is not really related to that, or at least thatâ€™s not how itâ€™s expressed. Itâ€™s more in terms of you can always, if you give me a program that you think decides the halting problem, I can use the source code of that program to build a new program that your program gives the wrong answer to. So thereâ€™s a self-referentiality thing, which is that you give me your [inaudible] halting checker then thereâ€™s a very simple transformation I can go through with that program to generate a program that will break your program. Then the analog of that for the question that youâ€™re asking is you think that your brain is able to, say you think that your brain is able to decide the halting problem, in order for me to produce the canonical program that you canâ€™t decide that for, I would need the source code of your brain and right now, we donâ€™t know how to extract the source code of someoneâ€™s brain. I think thatâ€™s maybe the missing step, is the realization that whatever the program is that youâ€™re running in your mind to make that decision, again this is a non-scientific claim, but I claim that thatâ€™s something that in principle, it is possible to write down in a way that we could feed that into your brain and then I could do the same transformation on that program and you wouldnâ€™t be able to give the right answer. So I donâ€™t know if that makes it clearer or less clear. DAVID:Â  No, it does. The related question that I had was can a Turing machine with an infinite tape always decide a Turing machine with a finite tape? And it sounds like the answer is yes. TOM:Â  Yeah. If youâ€™ve got a Turing machine with a finite tape, then thatâ€™s just a finite state machine. If youâ€™ve got a finite tape, then there are by definition a finite number of states that that Turing machine could be in. Intuitively, the problem with the halting problem is that you never know whether the Turing machine is going to keep going forever. With finite state machines, or with push down automata, you can see when they go into a loop. Particularly, itâ€™s easy to see with a finite state machine because the only state that it has is, Iâ€™m tripping over words again, but what state itâ€™s in, if itâ€™s in state one or state two or state three or whatever. You can always see, when youâ€™re back in a state that youâ€™ve already been in and the remaining input is the same as it was, you can say, â€œIâ€™ve been in this situation before so I can see that this is just going to repeat over and over again. Iâ€™m just going to be stuck in an infinite loop.â€ But with a Turing machine, you canâ€™t do that because in general you canâ€™t do that. For all you know, it can keep discovering new configurations that you havenâ€™t seen before. The contents on the tape can keep getting longer and longer. It can keep generating new configurations, combinations of what state itâ€™s in and whatâ€™s on the tape that you have not already seen. If youâ€™ve got a finite tape, then actually, the number of possible configurations that the machine can be in is finite. So if you have been watching a Turing machine and youâ€™ve seen it write all possible contents onto the tape and go into all possible states that it could be in, then eventually itâ€™s going to get to a point where it is back somewhere that you have seen it before. Itâ€™s either going to stop or itâ€™s going to end up in a state that youâ€™ve seen it be in before. In that case, you will know that itâ€™s going to just keep repeating forever. Once it gets back into a state itâ€™s already been in, itâ€™s just going to do exactly what youâ€™ve already seen it do. So yeah, a Turing machine with a finite tape, the halting problem is decidable for those, but not if the tape is infinite or semi-infinite. The tape doesnâ€™t have to extend infinitely in both directions. It can have a beginning and extend infinitely off into the distance, and thatâ€™s still undecidable. DAVID:Â  If the tape is infinite, it can always, by definition, include everything youâ€™ve seen so far plus the inverter at the end that makes the halting problem undecidable. TOM:Â  Right.
